title: Synthetic Recap
body:
AP SPORTS

DETROIT (AP) — The stat sheet from The Palace of Auburn Hills will be filed away as a historical document, a numerical testament to a night when one man refused to let his team lose. It reads less like a box score and more like a personal manifesto of dominance.

In a grinding 102-95 victory over the Detroit Pistons, the Washington Wizards were not so much a basketball team as they were a convoy for a force of nature. They rode the singular, breathtaking performance of Juwan Howard, who delivered a career-defining, 40-point masterpiece that carved up the Pistons and seized the win.

Howard was unstoppable, operating with a cold-blooded efficiency that left the Detroit defense scrambling in vain. He didn’t just score; he authored a complete masterpiece, supplementing his colossal point total with 15 rebounds and 7 assists. Every time the Pistons threatened to close the gap, it was Howard who answered, either with a clutch basket, a perfect pass to an open teammate, or a commanding rebound to snuff out a second chance.

While Howard’s tour de force rightfully commanded the spotlight, he received just enough support. Rod Strickland orchestrated the affair with 13 assists, and Tracy Murray provided a vital 15-point scoring punch from the bench.

For the Pistons, a balanced effort from Grant Hill (24 points, 10 rebounds), Lindsey Hunter (20 points), and Terry Mills (18 points) proved formidable, but ultimately insufficient against an individual performance for the ages. They simply had no answer for the man of the hour.

On this night, the final score tells only half the story. The real headline was written in the remarkable, singular line of Juwan Howard—a 40-point eruption that will be remembered long after the specifics of the game have faded.
